newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Two Hungary c.bank officials offer to resign - paper.
newsitem.headline: Two Hungary c.bank officials offer to resign - paper.

text.p: Two top National Bank of Hungary (NBH) officials offered to resign after disclosure of an unfavourable foreign exchange contract that could cost the NBH more than three billion forints ($19 million), newspapers said on Monday.

The reports of a huge loss in a government contract came hard on the heels of a scandal over payments of millions of dollars to a consultant at the state privatisation agency APV Rt. That revelation led to the dismissal of the entire APV board and the minister in charge.
NBH vice presidents Frigyes Harshegyi and Sandor Czirjak offered their resignations over the contract with Creditanstalt which the NBH concluded in 1992, the daily Nepszabadsag said.
The latest contract was for foreign exchange rate guarantees maturing in 1998 that forced the NBH to create substantial risk reserves that have proven extremely costly, the newspaper reports said.
Government spokesman Elemer Kiss told the daily Magyar Hirlap that Prime Minister Gyula Horn was likely to decide on Monday what action he would take.
An internal report by the NBH said "a professional mistake was made" by those responsible for the contract and added that Czirjak and Harshegyi were "personally responsible".
The government discussed the report last week in a cabinet meeting and said that although the two vice presidents had worked effectively at the bank, action must be taken.
Officials at Creditanstalt were not immediately available for comment. ($1=159.24 Forint)
